e4: I recommended not changing to the new policy because, despite some inaccuracies in reporting and potential harm to retail investors under the current method - where investors are effectively 'adding back' a previously withheld amount of nearly $20 ($10 x 9 years or nearly two decades)-  while the newer format seems cleaner it leaves large informed traders ahead of weaker less perceptive (or even financially worse off) investors creating an unfair marketplace. It’s better to be aware your earnings are slightly lower than what you thought - rather than having your trust in company finances broken and subsequently trading further behind as the reality sets in .
e5: For a reporting policy to be considered ethical, it should provide investors with the most accurate and transparent information about the company's financial performance. This means consistently revealing both successes and setbacks, without intentional biases or omissions that can unfairly influence market behaviors. It also suggests not withholding crucial details to maintain an artificially positive public image or shield interests from less informed ones (who may also be more vulnerable), instead aiming for honesty even if that truth implies a temporary hardship.
e6: Yes. What specific measures will be taken to minimize any temporary adverse market reaction expected under the new policy? And, how might employee incentives and compensation structures relate to potential performance changes post-policy- switch.
